subject: Introduce a policy to govern the deletion of deactivated images

values.-1: This patch needs further work before it can be merged
values.+1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I don't think this is a bug; see my comments on https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1522524

If we decide that we want to make this change, I'd argue that (1) it's an enhancement, and (2) it needs to be controlled by either configuration or policy, because allowing deletion of a deactivated image is up to the deployer, not up to Glance.  For example, depending upon how billing is done in a cloud, a deployer may not want it to be the case that a user is being charged for an image that the user cannot use.

Anyway, I'd like to see some more discussion of this.

Patch Set 1:

@Brian I have responded on the bug.

Patch Set 1:

Thanks, Niall.  I responded on the bug.  Basically, I still think this is an enhancement and needs to be discussed among the broader Glance community.

Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Soo, looks like that needs to be configurable in glance-api conf.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2

(1 comment)

I don't think this is something we can consider a bug and let it in. I'd like to see a proper spec for it as it's effectively changing the behavior of our API (sure using a config option) and it's adding a new config option.

I've seen some patches around the deactivation "feature" in the last release and I'm starting to wonder if that's thought thoroughly enough and whether we might need a proper spec to "fix it" or "enhance it".

Thanks, Niall.

Patch Set 5:

@Flavio I did wonder If this now needed a spec after adding a config option. I thought it would be best to push it up and see what others thought.

In situations like this is it normal practice to propose a new spec or modify the current spec that covers the deactivation feature?

I agree here we have too many config options. I'm not sure what the best policy to resolve this would be based on some members of the community wanting to keep the status quo.

Patch Set 5: Verified-1

Merge Failed.

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. Please rebase the change and upload a new patchset.

Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

I don't like adding another config option for this. 

How about this random thought. Instead of yet another config option, how about governing the deletion of deactivated images through policy?
We already have a 'deactivate' policy that governs who can deactivate a certain image. That very policy should also be able to govern who can delete the deactivated images as well. Because, that is precisely what we want here, right? We want only those people who deactivated the image be able to delete the deactivated image as well. 

So, why not enforce the same policy here?

 if image['status'] == 'deactivated':
     self._enforce(req, 'deactivate')

Does that make any sense?

Patch Set 5:

Enforcing 'deactivate' policy for deletion maybe a tad confusing though, I must admit.

Patch Set 5:

I think Hemanth is onto something.  Suppose you add this:

    if image['status'] == 'deactivated':
        self._enforce(req, 'delete_deactivated_image')

I'm pretty sure that if a policy isn't mentioned in the policy.json, anyone is allowed to do it.  So if no changes are made to policy.json, an operator would have the current behavior.  What's nice about a policy instead of a config option is that it gives an operator more options about who can do the action.  With the config option, you have simply either (a) an admin and nobody else can do it, or (b) an admin and everyone else can do it.  With a policy, an operator could add a security team role to some non-admin users who could also do the action (probably not a good example in this context, but you get the point).

Patch Set 5:

I think I like the policy idea better.

The question now is: Should we add a new one or re-use the one we have? At this point, I'm leaning towards using the same one, mostly for consistency reasons.

Using `deactivate` for one thing and then `delete_deactivate` for another thing might be super confusing. We can rename the policy in the future if we need to.

The important thing is that the current behavior mustn't change.

Thoughts?

Patch Set 5:

The problem with using the same policy for both is that I don't see how you can preserve the current behavior.

Current behavior: 'deactivate' is admin only, 'delete' (even of a deactivated image) is admin-or-owner.

I could see a use case for making 'deactivate' admin-or-owner, namely, a user could share an image, get a report that there's a problem, and deactivate it on his own while he investigates ...  except, we certainly don't want to make 'reactivate' admin-or-owner, so this would leave a user with the ability to pull an image out of circulation, but not have the ability to put it back into circulation.  Thus, a responsible image owner would have to call support no matter to get an image active again, might as well let a responsible image owner call support in the first place to deactivate an image if a problem is suspected.

On the third hand, my comment on the original bug was that the current behavior is exactly as originally designed, i.e., there had been discussion at the time of the blueprint (I think this was pre-spec-days), and this was the agreed-upon behavior.  So I didn't think we should change the behavior without further discussion.  Maybe someone should circulate an email on the operators' list to see if any actual operators have an opinion on this?  While the ability to deactivate an image was a high-priority operator request, it would be interesting to know how many people actually use it, and what they think of tying the deactivate-image and delete-deactivated-image policies tightly together.  (Personally, I think it makes sense to keep them separate, but I'm open-minded.)

Patch Set 5:

Let's wait until Newton before we do this. The reason being, there seem to be quite a few options to fix this issue and it doesn't look like it's critical enough for us to rush a "fix" for it, which is not the ideal one.

If someone disagrees, please do let me know.

Patch Set 5:

I'm happy to leave to Newton. As its causing a discussion on what the best way to do it is, better not to rush.
Uploaded patch set 6.

Patch Set 8:

Now that Newton's open for business, maybe Flavio can remove his -2 and we can reopen.  I personally like the approach taken with this latest patch, namely, to control via policy instead of config option.  Niall, it's probably worth putting this on the agenda for the weekly Glance meeting, not simply because of the topic of this bug, but to bring to the team's attention this pattern of fixing it.

Patch Set 9:

There was some discussion around a spec for this.

I think we should add this policy (and the reason for it) to doc/source/policies.rst. I'm not sure duplicating that in a spec adds much to be honest.

Patch Set 9:

I agree with Stuart about this.  The current behavior is the default with the new policy, so no API impact to mention.  The new policy-governed behavior can be described in a release-note yaml file.  So I think, let's skip the spec-lite and Niall, you can just add a releasenotes.yaml to this patch.

Patch Set 9:

Added Erno to the review, as he was pro-spec-lite on this.  Erno, what do you think of skipping the spec and just documenting in releasenotes?

Patch Set 13: Code-Review+2

Looks good!

Just a note to answer my question on an earlier patch: The oslo docs say that "", [], and "@" are all equivalent and will always accept an access.  "!" rejects all accesses.
http://docs.openstack.org/developer/oslo.policy/api.html

Patch Set 13: Code-Review-1

We don't need to check that policy in code TBH and it can be managed by users.
For example, you can specify the following rule in /etc/policy.json:
delete_deactivated_image: 'deactivated':%(status)s' and rule:context_is_admin or not 'deactivated':%(status)s
delete_image: rule: delete_deactivated_image ..
See more examples for Glare:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/343777/1/glance/common/glare/policy.py
In that case policy will be applied to the case you are trying to achieve. 
So maybe we should stop introduce new policies and use existing functionality. What do you think, guys?

Patch Set 13:

@Kairat This did have a spec lite that was merged here: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/301015/.

However about your point, to me at least, that looks like an overly complicated way to do it. I think it would benefit the users much more to be able to easily see what policy has what effect.

When implementing rules like this the more simple it is the less likely a mistake will be made and a potential security situation will arise.
Patch Set 13: Workflow+1
Patch Set 13: -Workflow

Patch Set 13:

Yep, I saw that spec merged. Nevertheless, we need to implement the best solution despite the fact that spec was merged.
The rule doesn't seem complex to me to be honest and this is the kind of case that policy must cover. The separate policy is simple but from the other point of view it gets messy because delete_image policy doesn't cover all cases for deletion and users need to know that delete_deactivated_image policy also must be updated to manage image deletion. Additionally, if users NOW have an instrument to manage deletion of deactivated images why do we need to duplicate that? So could you please clarify why do we need to duplicate functionality now and support it forever because once this policy will be release we cannot delete it.
Nevertheless, it is community so the points above describe only my opinion=)

Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1

I think Kairat raises a very good point, so downgrading to +1 for now.  Let's discuss this at the Glance meeting this week.  Sorry to do this to you Niall, since as you point out, the spec was accepted.

I think the downside of Kairat's suggestion is that if we leave it up to the operator to write the rules, the operator may miss an edge case or something, whereas with the in-code solution, we have tests to verify that the particular behavior of interest is enforced based on that policy.  So I think if we take the operator-configuration route, we should probably write a "cookbook" for how to configure the policy file to achieve specific use-cases, and then we could also have tests to make sure the behavior is correct for the documented use-case.  But this might be more of a pain than introducing/maintaining a specific policy-per-use-case.

I really don't know, I think this could use some discussion.

Patch Set 13:

please see how nova did it:

Patch Set 13: Workflow-1

Tested again and looks a bit out of date now.

@Kiarat However a policy can't add more permissions to something. If I have delete_images: "" which should be everything. A user is restricted to still deleting their own images or if they are an admin (which is tested in code as far as i understand). So i don't think it is possible currently as it does not allow for more than if you set everything to anybody.

So to be able to implement this same functionality we would have to have delete_images mean ALL images and then could do delete_images:"there own and if in this group deactivated".
